definitions: The rate at which velocity increases over time (change in velocity divided by time).
How quickly an athlete can increase speed from a standstill or slower speed.
The ability to gain speed rapidly by producing high horizontal force early in a sprint.
A performance quality most apparent in the first steps of sprinting (start and early drive phase).
A change in velocity per unit time, involving both magnitude and direction when applicable.
The phase of sprinting where propulsion and forward lean are emphasized to build speed.
In sport, the capacity to beat an opponent to space by reaching higher speeds sooner.
A kinematic variable describing increasing motion speed; influenced by force application and technique.
The ability to rapidly change direction and/or speed in response to an external stimulus.
Change-of-direction skill plus decision-making (reacting to an opponent, ball, or cue).
A sport-specific capacity combining physical deceleration and reacceleration with perception and reaction.
The ability to execute rapid movement changes while maintaining balance, control, and speed under uncertainty.
A quality requiring both physical capacities (strength, power) and cognitive components (anticipation).
A reactive movement skill where the athlete must select and execute the correct movement pattern quickly.
Fast, controlled repositioning of the body in response to information from the environment.
A hallmark of many field/court sports: quick reorientation driven by stimulus recognition and response.
The ability to decelerate, change direction, and reaccelerate in a pre-planned manner.
Directional change performed without a reactive stimulus (the movement is known in advance).
A physical skill emphasizing braking control, body reorientation, and propulsion into a new direction.
A planned maneuver where technique and force production determine how efficiently direction is changed.
The capacity to redirect momentum under control when the target direction is predetermined.
A movement task where deceleration strength and mechanics strongly influence performance and injury risk.
Planned cutting ability: stop/plant/turn/go executed as instructed, not in reaction to an opponent.
A deterministic movement quality focused on mechanics, strength, and power rather than decision-making.
Pairing a heavy resistance exercise with a biomechanically similar high-velocity movement to enhance performance.
A training method that sequences strength work and an explosive counterpart (e.g., squat then jump).
A strength-to-power bridging approach often used to improve rate of force development and power expression.
A pairing strategy designed to leverage post-activation effects to improve the next explosive effort.
A method combining high-load and high-velocity stimuli within the same session for enhanced transfer.
A contrast-style approach linking force capacity (heavy lift) and rapid force application (plyo/ballistic).
A sequencing method where a heavy exercise primes the nervous system for a similar explosive movement.
A way to train strength and explosiveness together using matched movement patterns.
A push or pull that can change an object’s motion (cause acceleration).
An interaction that can alter velocity, direction, or shape of an object.
A vector quantity with magnitude and direction that influences movement dynamics.
In human movement, the mechanical output produced by muscles and transmitted through the skeleton.
The cause of acceleration according to Newton’s second law (F = m·a).
A mechanical input that can speed up, slow down, or redirect the body or an implement.
In sport, the ability to apply force effectively against the ground or an external object.
A foundational mechanical variable underlying strength, braking, and propulsion.
Pre-activation strategies used to prepare the body to apply force efficiently during ground contact.
Muscle activation and stiffness set before impact to improve force transfer and reduce collapse at contact.
The anticipatory “bracing” of the lower limb and trunk to handle landing/stance forces effectively.
A preparatory neuromuscular action that improves reactive stiffness and shortens coupling time.
The act of getting the foot/ankle/knee/hip positioned and activated before touchdown for efficient mechanics.
Pre-contact tension that supports better SSC performance and reduces energy loss at ground contact.
A technique concept in sprinting/jumping: arrive “ready” to strike, stabilize, and rebound quickly.
An anticipatory control strategy that enhances performance by optimizing stiffness and alignment at contact.
The product of force and the time interval over which the force acts (F × t, or integral of force over time).
A measure of how much force is applied over time to change momentum.
The area under the force–time curve during a contact, push, or collision.
A mechanical quantity that determines the change in momentum of the body or an implement.
In sprint/jump, how force magnitude and contact duration combine to influence takeoff or acceleration.
The cumulative “push” delivered during ground contact that affects velocity change.
A concept linking contact strategy to outcome: more effective impulse generally yields greater momentum change.
Force applied over time that produces a change in motion (Δmomentum).
The product of mass and velocity (p = m·v).
A measure of how difficult it is to stop or change the motion of a moving object.
The quantity of motion of the body or an implement, dependent on both size and speed.
A vector describing motion that increases with either greater mass or greater velocity.
A mechanical property that must be redirected during cutting, tackling, or landing maneuvers.
In sport collisions, a key determinant of movement outcome along with impulse and momentum change.
The motion “carry” of an athlete that affects braking demands and direction-change requirements.
A kinematic-mechanical variable that is altered by applying impulse.
The systematic planning of training variables over time to optimize performance and manage fatigue.
A structured approach to varying volume, intensity, and exercise focus across weeks/months.
Organizing training into phases (cycles) that target specific adaptations at the right time.
Planned manipulation of training stress to improve performance peaks and reduce overtraining risk.
A long-term strategy that sequences goals (e.g., hypertrophy → strength → power → taper).
A method of training organization that balances overload and recovery across time.
A framework for progressing training by adjusting load and volume across macro/meso/microcycles.
A planning system used to build fitness while timing readiness for competition.
An acute enhancement of muscle performance following a conditioning contraction.
A short-term boost in force or power output after heavy or explosive activation work.
A phenomenon where prior contractions temporarily increase subsequent contractile responsiveness.
A priming effect used in contrast/complex training to improve jump, sprint, or throw performance.
A transient state where neuromuscular readiness is elevated following a heavy stimulus.
An acute performance enhancement driven by activation, often balanced against fatigue.
A mechanism exploited when a heavy lift precedes a similar explosive movement to improve output.
A temporary improvement in explosive performance after high-intensity muscular activity.
The speed at which force is produced (change in force divided by change in time).
How rapidly an athlete can generate force in the early portion of contraction or ground contact.
A critical quality for explosive actions where there is limited time to apply force (sprinting, jumping).
The slope of the force–time curve during force production.
A measure of explosive strength reflecting neural drive and muscle-tendon characteristics.
A performance capacity describing fast force expression rather than maximum force capacity alone.
The ability to reach high force levels quickly under time constraints.
A key determinant of explosive performance when contact times are short.
The restoration of physiological systems following training stress.
The process of returning to readiness by restoring energy stores and repairing tissue.
A period where fatigue dissipates and adaptation can occur after overload.
The return of performance capacity after training via sleep, nutrition, and reduced stress.
Rebuilding of homeostasis after exercise through replenishment and repair mechanisms.
A training variable involving time and strategies that restore function between sessions.
The reduction of accumulated fatigue to regain or improve performance.
The time and processes required for the body to recover from imposed training demands.
The ability to move the body or a body part quickly.
The rate of motion, typically describing how fast displacement occurs over time.
In sport, the capacity to reach and maintain high running velocity.
A performance quality influenced by technique, force application, and neuromuscular properties.
How fast an athlete can move through space, often measured as distance per unit time.
A general term that can refer to sprinting velocity or limb movement velocity depending on context.
A kinematic descriptor of fast movement execution (linear or segmental).
The capability to produce rapid movement, often requiring both strength and coordination.
A biomechanical model describing the body as a spring-supported mass during running and jumping.
A framework where the leg behaves like a spring that compresses and recoils to propel the body.
A model explaining how stiffness and elastic return influence gait and jump mechanics.
A representation of locomotion emphasizing elastic energy storage and release in the lower limb.
A simplified running/jumping model: body mass supported by a spring-like leg during ground contact.
A conceptual tool used to describe how changes in leg stiffness affect performance and efficiency.
A model linking ground contact dynamics (compression/rebound) to speed and reactive qualities.
A biomechanical analogy where the body’s COM is the mass and the leg/tendon system acts as the spring.
Maximal or near-maximal running velocity.
High-intensity running where the athlete attempts to run as fast as possible.
A locomotor skill involving rapid force application and efficient mechanics to achieve top speed.
Running performed at very high velocities, typically requiring high neural and muscular output.
A performance action characterized by short ground contact times and high horizontal force demands.
Max-velocity or acceleration-based fast running depending on distance and phase.
An explosive running task relying on technique, reactive stiffness, and high force production.
The act of running at the upper end of one’s velocity capacity.
The ability to produce force.
The capacity of a muscle or muscle group to exert force against resistance.
A foundational quality that supports power, speed, and resilience when applied effectively.
The ability to generate high levels of force, often assessed with heavy lifting performance.
Force production capability that can be expressed isometrically or dynamically.
A physical trait reflecting neural and muscular factors that allow high force output.
The ability to overcome or resist external resistance through muscular contraction.
A performance quality underpinning braking, pushing, and load-handling tasks.
A rapid sequence of eccentric, amortization, and concentric muscle actions used to enhance force and power.
A mechanism where a quick pre-stretch improves subsequent shortening action and performance.
Eccentric loading followed by a fast reversal that allows elastic recoil and reflex contribution.
A neuromechanical cycle that can increase force output compared with concentric-only actions.
A process where elastic energy is stored during braking and released during propulsion.
A performance mechanism requiring short coupling time to preserve stored energy and maximize output.
A foundational concept in plyometrics explaining why rapid stretch can enhance explosive movements.
An eccentric-to-concentric transition that boosts performance via elastic and neural contributions.
The rate of movement in a given direction (displacement per unit time).
A vector quantity describing both how fast something moves and the direction it moves.
Speed with direction included, distinguishing it from speed alone.
A kinematic variable that changes when acceleration occurs.
The directional rate of position change; can be linear or angular depending on context.
A motion descriptor that can increase, decrease, or change direction based on applied forces.
A fundamental movement variable used to describe sprinting, throwing, or lifting speed.
The time-based change in displacement that characterizes how motion progresses through space.
